Dear Amanda Garza:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
August 28, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must
include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action
plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions.
In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone immediately, please
contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the
equivalent state or Canadian provincial
2

agency, or equivalent agency in the
country where the person usually resides,
that the person has not been determined
to be a perpetrator of child abuse or child
neglect. The documentation shall be
One of nine new employees did not have a central registry clearance completed
within 30 days prior to hire. It was completed on 6/6/24 and the employee was
hired on 7/8/24.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an initial treatment plan for each resident
within 30 calendar days of admission.
One of three open files reviewed did not contain an initial treatment plan
completed within 30 days of admission. The youth was admitted to the facility on
5/22/24, but the ITP wasn't completed until 7/3/24.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(b) A brief summary or other documentation
of the services provided while in residence,
including medical and dental services.
Three of three closed files reviewed did not contain a summary of services
provided while in care, including medical and dental services.
CCI Rule 400.4166 Discharge plan
(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after
discharge:
(e) A statement that the discharge plan
recommendations, including medical and
dental follow up that is needed, have been
reviewed with the resident and with the parent
and with the responsible case manager.

(1) When a resident is discharged from institutional
care, all of the following information shall be
documented in the case record within 14 days after

(f) The name and official title of the person to

Three of three closed files reviewed did not contain the name and title of the

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Timeframes for document completion, medical exams, dentals, school
enrollment, etc. start the day a youth is admitted to the facility and continue
from that date unless youth is discharged from the facility. If youth go to a
juvenile facility, they should be discharged from Footprints. Then if they
come back to the facility, the youth would be considered a brand-new
readmission, and timeframes would start over from the date they're
readmitted.
• If the youth will be gone from the facility for more than a few days, the
agency should consider discharging them if timeframes are not going to be
met.
• Youth signatures on the treatment plans are option, but discussion with the
youth about their treatment plan needs to be documented somewhere in
the file (i.e. contact sheet, team meeting, signature on the treatment plan,
etc.)
• Agency should screenshot onboarding screen for new employees to
provide verification they signed off on their job description and add the
screenshot to the employee file.
V. CONSULTATION
The agency was offered consultation in the following areas:
• Discussed options for discussing the discharge plan with youth and
caregivers prior to discharging the youth.
• Discussed possibly utilizing the MDHHS Action Summary form as a way to
incorporate all discharge plan requirements.
4

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
There was one CAP during the period of review as a result of the agency's 2023
renewal audit. The agency had violations for late, incomplete, or not signed
treatment plans, and discharge plans. To address the agency implemented steps
which included monthly file audits, a tracking sheet within the file to confirm auditing
is taking place, a new treatment plan template requiring two staff signatures, and
the utilization of calendar reminders to ensure timely completion of service plans.
Financial Overview
The facility's budget and financial audit were reviewed, and no concerns were
noted.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) noted things are going very well at the agency right now.
She noted the supervisor position was open for 6 months, but was filled in July,
which was a positive change. CA noted there has been a lot of staff turnover, but
they have filled the positions, and even have more on call staff now as well. CA
noted high risk residents were the cause of most of the turnover in the spring, but
they have continued to demonstrate support for staff and increased safety for youth
as problems arise. CA noted they will continue holding weekly leadership meetings
and monthly file audits to ensure compliance with the rules.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported the program is good and very strengths based. Everyone supports
each other because it is a small staff network. Upper management and supervisors
fill in on shifts and responsibilities whenever needed, which also adds to staff
support. There is open communication, which is very important for the youth and
staff. Any safety issues, training needs, or changes in policy/procedure are well
5

communicated. Staff mentioned the medication tracking process could be
improved, but stated there is already progress in this area.
Youth reported they felt safe at the agency and staff were really nice. They reported
they feel supported by staff and could talk to them if they had a problem. Youth
reported they have enough food and like the food provided. There were no
concerns noted.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on 8/28/24, and there were no concerns
noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
